articles.headline: Russia Offers Cash Infusion for Ukraine
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia would provide $15 billion in loans and a sharp discount on natural gas prices, a bold move in his recent diplomatic battle with the West.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia would provide $15 billion in loans and a sharp discount on natural gas prices, a bold move in his recent diplomatic battle with the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a sharp rebuff to the West in the diplomatic wrangle over Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin said Tuesday that Russia would come to the rescue of its financially troubled neighbor, providing $15 billion in loans and a steep discount on natural gas prices.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: In Facebook News Feeds, Here Come Commercials
articles.snippet: Starting this week, Facebook will introduce video advertisements into the news feeds of its users, a push for more ad revenue that may not be liked by everyone.
articles.abstract: Starting this week, Facebook will introduce video advertisements into the news feeds of its users, a push for more ad revenue that may not be liked by everyone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook is betting the patience of some of its users against the hundreds of millions of dollars it could make on video advertisements.

articles.headline: Tech Leaders and Obama Find Shared Problem: Fading Public Trust
articles.snippet: A meeting that started with discussions about the federal health care site shifted quickly to the concerns over National Security Agency spying.
articles.abstract: A meeting that started with discussions about the federal health care site shifted quickly to the concerns over National Security Agency spying.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama met with top technology industry executives on Tuesday to discuss two seemingly distinct controversies: a faulty health care website, and the digital surveillance practices of the National Security Agency.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Brash Agent at William Morris Extends Reach in IMG Merger
articles.snippet: Ari Emanuel’s company, working with its private equity partner, Silver Lake Partners, won a bidding war with an offer of about $2.3 billion.
articles.abstract: Ari Emanuel’s company, working with its private equity partner, Silver Lake Partners, won a bidding war with an offer of about $2.3 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:22 p.m. | Over the past two decades, Ari Emanuel has climbed — brashly, ruthlessly — into Hollywood’s power center with one position in mind: king.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and David Gelles

articles.headline: Senate Asks C.I.A. to Share Its Report on Interrogations
articles.snippet: The Senate Intelligence Committee has asked the C.I.A. for an internal study that lawmakers believe is broadly critical of the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program.
articles.abstract: The Senate Intelligence Committee has asked the C.I.A. for an internal study that lawmakers believe is broadly critical of the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee has asked the C.I.A. for an internal study done by the agency that lawmakers believe is broadly critical of the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program but was withheld from congressional oversight committees.

articles.headline: In the War on Poverty, a Dogged Adversary
articles.snippet: Despite continued efforts to help the poor, the poverty level remains close to what it was 50 years ago.
articles.abstract: Despite continued efforts to help the poor, the poverty level remains close to what it was 50 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Lyndon Johnson declared his war on poverty on Jan. 8, 1964, almost exactly 50 years ago, 19 percent of Americans were poor.

articles.headline: Applying Creativity to a Byproduct of Oil Drilling
articles.snippet: A surge in emissions — and criticism — has prompted energy executives to find ways to capture gas being flared during drilling in North Dakota.
articles.abstract: A surge in emissions — and criticism — has prompted energy executives to find ways to capture gas being flared during drilling in North Dakota.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATFORD CITY, N.D. — Viewed from outer space, the 1,500 blazing oil well flares burning off excess natural gas illuminate the plains of western North Dakota more brilliantly than Minneapolis hundreds of miles away.

articles.headline: ABC Viewers Tilt Female for a Network Light on Sports
articles.snippet: For ABC, every important ratings measure in prime time is qualified by what amounts to a footnote: “not counting sports.”
articles.abstract: For ABC, every important ratings measure in prime time is qualified by what amounts to a footnote: “not counting sports.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The first initial in the ABC television network stands for “American,” but it might well stand for “asterisk.”

articles.headline: Budget Deal Offers a Reprieve From Washington Paralysis
articles.snippet: The bipartisan budget deal may not be a cure-all for the gridlock in Washington, but it provides a much-needed break in the inaction.
articles.abstract: The bipartisan budget deal may not be a cure-all for the gridlock in Washington, but it provides a much-needed break in the inaction.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Something odd happened here on Tuesday. The Senate advanced a two-year bipartisan budget deal that will now surely be sent to the president for his signature later this week without waiting for a cliff, a chasm, a deadline or a shutdown to force its hand.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Paper or Plastic? Britain Joining Currency Trend
articles.snippet: Canada, Australia and dozens of other countries use polymer bank notes, and the Bank of England has just decided to make the switch.
articles.abstract: Canada, Australia and dozens of other countries use polymer bank notes, and the Bank of England has just decided to make the switch.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — It took only 900 years, but paper money is fading away.
articles.byline: By Ian Austen and Nathaniel Popper
